result.content:
Hello!

From now on i will be posting information and tutorials on this page, instead of Facebook. If you have a question for me specifically you can email me at reem_obaid_10@hotmail.com , or you could post any question you have on the Facebook group. But summaries will be here since most Facebook groups get crowded with questions.

Yesterday we solved some problems from week 2 contest. For those who simply copied the code, go back and try to rewrite it yourself. If you are having any difficulties with syntax or missed last weeks lecture, you can either check the day 1 post or watch these videos for anything specific.

A. Watermelon

This is the first problem we solved, it required you to output yes if you could split a watermelon into two parts, both of which are even and sum to the original watermelon. We discussed that the solution for this is that any even number greater than two, you can subtract two from it and the remainder will still be even. That is because the sum of two even numbers is always even. Also each part doesn't have to be equal so it will always work.

Here is the code we wrote for it : http://ideone.com/JkFN1V

B. Way Too Long Words

The problem required you to enter in n words, and for each one if the length of it is STRICTLY greater than 10, to output the abbreviation of it â€” otherwise the same word. The abbreviation of it is the first character, the length of the string minus the first and last character, then the last character.

To solve this we used a built in function called .size() for string which returns the length of the string. For more functions that could be useful, use this website : http://www.cplusplus.com/reference/string/string/

Here is the code for it : http://ideone.com/Moosjo

C. Team

The third problem is a programming competition and there is a team with 3 players and n problems. For each problem, if two or more are certain of their solution, they will solve the problem, otherwise they wont. In the end, you need to output how many problems they solved.

This problem just required for you to use a for loop, enter in the three numbers, and if the sum of them is greater than or equal to 2, add to a counter than is initialized to zero outside of the for loop.

Here is the code we wrote for it : http://ideone.com/BIKGkP

The last two problems seem complicated, but always think simply. Think twice, code once.

Best of luck! I will be posting up problems to solve by next week, please have them solved so the next class everything goes smoothly. Everything so far is easy to catch up to. Just don't let yourself get more behind than this :)
